data.title: The Basil Rathbone - Sherlock Holmes film-by-film discussion (part 2)
data.meta_description: This was without a doubt, arguably the best of the Universal series. These were the biggest roles for the supporting actors. Arthur Hohl and Gerald...
data.text:
SH#11 – The Woman In Green (1945) (Working title – An Invitation to Death)

Director and Producer – Roy William Neill

Sherlock Holmes investigates when young women around London turn up murdered, each with a finger severed off. Scotland Yard suspects a madman, but Holmes believes the killings to be part of a diabolical plot.

The Players

Basil Rathbone-Sherlock Holmes

Nigel Bruce-Dr. John H. Watson

Hillary Brooke-Lydia

Henry Daniell-Professor Moriarty

Paul Cavanagh-Sir George Fenwick

Matthew Boulton-Inspector Gregson

Eve Amber-Maude “…stealing through his own garden like a thief”

Frederick Worlock-Onslow (as Frederic Worlock) "..charlatans and crooks..."

Coulter Irwin-Williams (as Tom Bryson) "..sniper..."

Sally Shepherd-Crandon “Yes, mum”

Mary Gordon-Mrs. Hudson

Fred Aldrich-Detective (uncredited)

Eve Ashley-Background woman (uncredited)

Frank Baker-Club Patron (uncredited)

John Burton-Waring - Mesmerist (uncredited)

Paul Cristo-Restaurant Patron (uncredited)

Harold De Becker-Shoelace Seller (uncredited) “shoelaces, guv’ner?”

Leslie Denison-Vincent, Barman at Pembroke House (uncredited)

Tony Ellis-Carter - Hypnotized Subject (uncredited)

Kay Harding-4th Victim (uncredited)

Alec Harford-Commissioner of the CID (uncredited)

Ivo Henderson-Constable (uncredited)

Tommy Hughes-Newsman (uncredited) "Morning paper, all about the horrible murder!"

Colin Hunter-Constable (uncredited)

Olaf Hytten-Norris - Fenwick's Butler (uncredited)

Boyd Irwin-Short-Tempered Officer Closing Window (uncredited)

Kermit Maynard-Detective (uncredited)

Eric Mayne-Member of Mesmer Club (uncredited)

William H. O'Brien-Pembrook House Waiter (uncredited)

Violet Seton-Nurse Mowbray at Mesmer House (uncredited)

Arthur Stenning-Mesmer Club Porter (uncredited) "I'll tell Dr. Onslow that you're here"

Percival Vivian-Dr. Simnell (uncredited) “Nasty things, splinters. Most trying...”

Disguises – none

Locations referenced

Pembroke House

Lambert Way

Edgeware Road

Montevideo

McArthur Mews (sp?)

Mesmer Club

Modern technology:

record player

tars

telephones

torch (flashlight)

Players that appeared in other SH films:

Ivo Henderson (2nd of 2) Constable

Henry Danielle (3rd of 3) Moriarty

Olaf Hytton (4th of 6) Norris

Hillary Brooke (3rd of 3) Lydia

Arthur Stenning (3rd of 3) Mesmer Porter

Alec Harford (2nd of 2) CID Commissioner

Leslie Denison (6th of 6) bartender

Harold DeBecker (4th of 4) Shoelace seller

John Burton (4th of 4) Waring

Frederick Worlock (3rd of 3) Onslow

Paul Cavanaugh (3rd of 3) Sir George Fenwick

Kay Harding (2nd of 2) 4th murder victim

Sally Shepherd (2nd of 3) Crandon

Boyd Irwin (1st of 2) window closer

Film Notes:

The last Sherlock Holmes story in this series written by Bertram Milhauser

Although "The Woman in Green" is credited as an original story, dialogue is lifted from Arthur Conan Doyle's "The Final Problem," and the situation involving the sniper firing at Holmes' silhouette is taken from the next story in the original canon, "The Empty House."

Although he is not seen, the only reference to Mycroft Holmes in the Basil Rathbone / Nigel Bruce series is made in this film.

Like Scarlet Claw, this film has a more serious tone, that it excludes Lestrade from the story, instead has Inspector Gregson. Thus, leaving most, if not all the humor for Watson to convey, such as the rushing off to a medical emergency, and going across the street, seeing the ape umbrella stand and the scene at the Mesmer Club.

It has been noted that Basil Rathbone regarded Henry Danielle's Moriarty as being "delectably dangerous".

End Quote:

I’m thinking of all the women that can come and go in safety on the streets of London tonight. Stars keep watch on the heavens, and in our own little way, we too old friend are privileged to watch over our city.

SH #12 Pursuit to Algiers

Director and Producer – Roy William Neill

Holmes is recruited to escort the heir to a European throne safely back to his homeland after his father's assassination.

The Players

Basil Rathbone-Sherlock Holmes

Nigel Bruce-Dr. John H. Watson

Marjorie Riordan-Sheila Woodbury

Rosalind Ivan-Agatha Dunham “Where would we be without the cow?”

Morton Lowry-Sanford

Leslie Vincent-Nikolas Watson

Martin Kosleck-Mirko “Satisfied?”

Rex Evans-Gregor “We are in accord, Mr Holmes”

John Abbott-Childry

Gerald Hamer-Kingston

William 'Wee Willie' Davis-Gubec (as Wee Willie Davis)

Frederick Worlock-Prime Minister (as Frederic Worlock) “The best fish and chips in London!”

Wilson Benge-Mr. Arnold - Minister (uncredited)

Sven Hugo Borg-Johansson (uncredited)

Ernst Brengt-Ship's Bar Patron (uncredited)

James Carlisle-Aide (uncredited)

Ashley Cowan-Steward (uncredited)

James Craven-Anton Petzval - Customer (uncredited) “Fishbones – I’d rather eat in an alley!”

Sayre Dearing-Aide (uncredited)

Tom Dillon-Matthias Cherney - Restaurant Proprietor (uncredited) “We make the best fish and chips…”

John Dutra-Sailor steering Boat (uncredited)

Alan Edmiston-Man with Newspaper (uncredited) “You dropped your paper…”

Curt Furburg-Ship's Bar Patron (uncredited)

Gregory Gaye-Ravez (uncredited)

Olaf Hytten-Stimson - the Gunsmith (uncredited)

Dorothy Kellogg-Blonde Floozie at Bar (uncredited) “Hello, Ducky!”

George Leigh-Reginald Dene (uncredited)

Charles Millsfield-Ship's Bar Patron (uncredited)

Sam Savitsky-Ship Passenger (uncredited)

Disguises - Sanford (King Niklaus), Niklaus Watson (decoy)

Locations referenced:

Scotland

Soho Oyster Bar

Fishbone Alley

Rovenia

Lisbon

Rock of Gilbraltar

Algiers

Technology of the time:

Electric lights

Cars

Ocean Freighter

Songs performed:

There Isn’t Any Harm In That

Cross My Heart

Flow Gently, Sweet Afton

Loc Lomond

Players that appeared in other SH films:

Morton Lowry (2nd of 2) Sanford

Olaf Hytton (5 of 6) Stimson

James Craven (2nd of 2) Soho Oyster Bar Customer

Gerald Hamer (4th of 5) Kingston

Frederic Worlock (4th of 6) Prime Minister of Rovenia

William Benge (4th of 5) Mr. Arnold

Tom Dillon (1st of 2) Restaurant Proprietor

Film Notes:

"Unwatchable" say some; "Enjoyable" say others. Pursuit to Algiers is not a favorite among Sherlock Holmes fans. David Stuart Davies writes, "Pursuit to Algiers showed a decided decline in inventiveness and proved to be the weakest of the series." However, even the weakest film in a good series can be good entertainment. I find Pursuit to Algiers very enjoyable.

The film contains a couple of clever in-jokes for Holmes aficionados in the form of references to famous unrecorded cases for the Great Detective: at one point Watson begins to recite the tale of The Giant Rat of Sumatra (mentioned in Conan Doyle's "The Adventure of the Sussex Vampire"); whilst the action takes place aboard the S.S. Friesland (from Conan Doyle's "The Adventure of the Norwood Builder", and alluded to as "a Dutch-American liner" in his Professor Challenger book "The Lost World", though here it has links to Malmö in Sweden). The film also borrows some characters and events from "The Adventure of the Red Circle."

End Quote:

Holmes: Yes Watson, let me advise you. If you ever consider taking up another profession, never even think of becoming an actor!

Martin Kosleck (Mierko) from 1980:

Basil and I became great friends on the set of The Mad Doctor. We played partners in crime as well as roommates - very avant garde for the time. He and his wife Ouida gave magnificent parties and all of Hollywood attended them. I was invited until Ouida saw our film together. After that, she was very cold and unfriendly to me. I was very aware of her jealousy regarding Basil and he was helpless to intervene. However, by the time we worked on the Holmes film, it was like old times. Basil and I were a team again, even though my part was nothing. I get emotional thinking about how good a friend he was, always trying to get them to give me more lines. I recall telling him not to bother. I was just so glad to be working with my dear friend that the part was of no importance at all.

Watson, Nicklas, Holmes, Mierko (Martin Kosleck), and Gregor playing shuffleboard

"You're a gracious loser, Mr. Holmes"

Great, thanks for that.

SH#13 – Terror By Night (1946)

Director and Producer – Roy William Neill

When the fabled Star of Rhodesia diamond is stolen on a London to Edinburgh train and the son of its owner is murdered, Sherlock Holmes must discover which of his suspicious fellow passengers is responsible.

The Players

Basil Rathbone-Sherlock Holmes

Nigel Bruce-Dr. John H. Watson

Alan Mowbray-Maj. Duncan-Bleek

Dennis Hoey-Inspector Lestrade

Renee Godfrey-Vivian Vedder “Rather a nuisance, traveling by train…ain’t it?”

Frederick Worlock-Prof. William Kilbane

Mary Forbes-Lady Margaret Carstairs

Skelton Knaggs-Sands - Moran's Accomplice “Sherlock Holmes and the fat bloke…”

Billy Bevan-Passenger Car Attendant

Geoffrey Steele-Hon. Roland Carstairs

Gilbert Allen-Dining Car Steward (uncredited)

Harry Cording-Mock - Coffin Maker (uncredited) “Go on about your business!”

Boyd Davis-Inspector MacDonald (uncredited)

Gerald Hamer-Alfred Shallcross (uncredited) “I’m a collector…of teapots”

Leyland Hodgson-Train Conductor (uncredited)

Stuart Holmes-Man on Train Platform (uncredited)

Colin Kenny-Constable (uncredited)

Charles Knight-Guard (uncredited)

Janet Murdoch-Mrs. Shallcross (uncredited) “I warned you…”

Tom Pilkington-Baggage Car Attendant (uncredited) “Gives me something to do”

C. Aubrey Smith-Elderly gentleman on train station (uncredited)

Bobby Wissler-Mock's Son (uncredited)

Disguises – Major Duncan-Bleek (Col. Sebastion Moran)

Locations referenced:

Tower Bridge

Bow Bells – Church of St. Mary Le Bow

Euston Station

Rugby

Topham

Edinburgh

Players that appeared in other SH films:

Mary Forbes (3rd of 3) Lady Margaret

Leyland Hodgson (6th of 7) Conductor

Harry Cording (7th of 8) Mock

Gerald Hamer (5th of 5) Alfred Shalcross

Frederick Worlock (5th of 6) Prof. Kilbane

Charles Knight (3rd of 3) Guard

Colin Kenny (2nd of 2) Constable

Billy Bevan (2nd of 2) train attendant

Film Notes:

Terror by Night is not based on a Sherlock Holmes story, but the writers may have been inspired by "The Adventure of the Empty House." Some elements in the film that are also in that story are:

• Colonel Sebastian Moran as the villain;

• the air pistol as the weapon;

• the name Carstairs (In the story it is a place name. Ronald Adair "had been engaged to Miss Edith Woodley, of Carstairs.")

The idea of a secret compartment could be from "The Disappearance of Lady Frances Carfax."

• It is the shortest of the 14 Sherlock Holmes films with Rathbone and Bruce; it was also the biggest budget of any of the Universal Sherlock Holmes films.

• It was Dennis Hoey's last appearance as Lestrade; and

Alan Mowbray (Duncan-Bleek) played Lestrade in the 1933 film A Study in Scarlet.

The stolen teapot appears to have come from the Beacon Hotel.

The title is not a Biblical quotation from Psalms 91:5: "Thou shalt not be afraid for the terror by night".

Holmes tells Watson that Lestrade is giving a perfect imitation of Izaak Walton. Walton was an English writer of the 17th century and wrote the book; The Complete Angler.

End Quote:

Moran: Very clever Holmes, you got me, but you haven’t got the Star of Rhodesia.

Holmes: Oh, but I have. If in the dark I can substitute a big hulk like Lestrade for you, Colonel Moran, it’s no very great feat to switch a little thing like a diamond.

Excerpt from Michael Hoey’s (son of Dennis Hoey) 2011 book about the music scores used in the Universal Sherlock Holmes series:

With a tight 60 minute running time, Terror By Night was the shortest of all the Sherlock Holmes films. For some reason it began with an entirely new fanfare, replacing the theme that traditionally played over the Universal letters circling the globe, but then the film reverted to the standard Sherlock Holmes main title music. It is interesting to note that Sherlock Holmes Faces Death was the first film in the series not to have an original music score written. Universal’s attitude regarding the music used in its films seemed to be based largely on economics. Composers were hired to write the music for the studio’s larger budgeted films and the scores would be kept in the music library to be used over and over again in less important films. Frank Skinner wrote the original music for The Voice Of Terror, The Secret Weapon and In Washington. He had been under contract from Universal since 1936 and had written the scores for such films as Son Of Frankenstein (1939), Destry Rides Again (1939) and Tower Of London (1939). In the later years he would compose the music for Frances (1950), All That Heaven Allows (1955) and The Ugly American (1963). All of the nine remaining Sherlock Holmes films reused Skinners compositions, as well as the library music selected from various others composers’ works, that was rearranged and rerecorded with an orchestra to fit the timings for the new films. Skinner’s theme for the Sherlock Holmes main title would be repeated in everyone one of the subsequent films. A musical director would be assigned to select the appropriate music and conduct the orchestra on the scoring session. In later years, studios could use “canned music” to score their TV shows, but in the 1940s the American Federation of Musicians and its leader James C. Petrillo demanded that each score be recorded by an orchestra. At first, these musical directors, most of whom were under contract to Universal and composers in there own right, Hans J. Salter, who was musical director under Faces Death and The Spider Woman.

Towards the end of the series however, the studio began using musical directors who were not predominantly composers such as Mark Levant (The Woman In Green), who had been the concert master for Metro, Edgar Fairchild (Pursuit To Algiers) who had been at the studio for many years and had been Deanna Durbin’s musical director, and Milton Rosen (Terror By Night and Dressed To Kill), who had contributed to many Universal films and serials. By 1946, the studio was in a midst of transition and soon would be controlled by the former president of RKO Pictures, Leo Spitz, and the former 20th Century-Fox executive, William Goetz. Perhaps that was the reason that Milton Rosen chose to have both Terror By Night and Dressed To Kill begin with dramatic new fanfare, replacing the old theme that traditionally played over the Universal logo. By the end of the year, the logo itself would be gone, and an entirely new image would introduce Universal-International Pictures, the studio’s new name, on all it’s forthcoming films. An edict would announce, “henceforth no feature that bore the Universal-International imprimatur would run under 70 minutes.” The day of the studio’s B pictures was coming to an end, but there was still time for one last Sherlock Holmes film that would begin life as Prelude To Murder.

SH#14 – Dressed To Kill (1946) (Prelude to Murder, UK title: Sherlock Holmes and The Secret Code)

Director and Producer – Roy William Neill

A convicted thief in Dartmoor prison hides the location of the stolen Bank of England printing plates inside three music boxes. When the innocent purchasers of the boxes start to be murdered, Holmes and Watson investigate.

The Players

Basil Rathbone-Sherlock Holmes

Nigel Bruce-Dr. John H. Watson

Patricia Morison-Mrs. Hilda Courtney

Edmund Breon-Julian 'Stinky' Emery “a collector buys but never sells”

Frederick Worlock-Colonel Cavanaugh "by now Holmes will be trading his fiddle for a harp"

Carl Harbord-Inspector Hopkins

Patricia Cameron-Evelyn Clifford (Gift Shop proprietor)

Holmes Herbert-Ebenezer Crabtree (Auctioneer) “lend me your ears…”

Harry Cording-Hamid “but a fool may touch a star…”

Leyland Hodgson-Tour Guide “gout. Just gout”

Mary Gordon-Mrs. Hudson

Ian Wolfe-Commissioner of Scotland Yard

Harry Allen-Scottish Man at Auction (Mr Kilgore)

Frank Baker-Photographer

Guy Bellis-Doctor

Wilson Benge-Minister on Museum Tour (uncredited) “is that really important, my dear?”

Marjorie Bennett-Antique Shop Assistant (uncredited) “I’ll make us a cup of tea”

Ted Billings-Pub Patron (uncredited) "you never know just who you're going to meet"

Lillian Bronson-Minister's Wife (uncredited) "...and it's not a Reynolds"

Cyril Delevanti-Convict at Dartmoor Prison (Davidson)

Tom Dillon-Detective Sergeant Thompson

Topsy Glyn-The Kilgour Child

Charlie Hall-Cab Driver (uncredited)

Olaf Hytten-Alfred - Auction House Bookkeeper

Boyd Irwin-Detective with X-ray Photos

Tiny Jones-Pub Patron (uncredited)

Guy Kingsford-Undercover Convict in Dartmoor Prison

William H. O'Brien-Detective at Murder Scene

Alexander Pollard-Crabtree's Assistant at Auction

Wallace Scott-Joe Cisto (Pub Piano Player) - "that tune is called 'A Swagman'"

Anita Sharp-Bolster-Teacher on Museum Tour "come along, children"

Sally Shepherd-Tobacconist "with just a hint of latakia for extra body..."

Disguises – Kilgore child woman, Miss Williams (Courtney)

Real locations in England:

Dartmoor Prison

Portsman Square

Hampton Way (Hampden Way)

Park Lane

Knightsbridge

Bryanston Square

Golders Green

Twickenham

Surrey

Songs –

Danny Boy (performed by Holmes on the violin)

Ya never know just ‘oo you’re gonna meet (performed by a busker)

Players that appeared in other SH films:

Holmes Herbert (6th of 6) Auctioneer Crabtree

Olaf Hytton (6th of 6) Alfred (man at desk during auction)

Leyland Hodgson (7th of 7) Tour guide

Ted Vincent (3rd of 3) pub extra

Harry Cording (8th of 8) Hamid

Guy Kingsford (2nd of 2) undercover convict

Ian Wolfe (4th of 4) Police Commissioner

Frederick Worlock (6th of 6) Colonel Cavanaugh

Willliam Benge (5th of 5) minister on tour

Lillian Bronson (2nd of 2) minister’s wife

Sally Shepherd (3rd of 3) tobacconist

Boyd Irwin (2nd of 2) X-ray Detective

Tom Dillon (2nd of 2) Sgt. Thompson

Film notes:

Sherlock Holmes and the Secret Code – a.k.a. Dressed To Kill – is the final film in the series, and a fine film it is too. There's a great cameo by Edmund Breon as 'Stinky' Emery, and the glamorous Patricia Morison plays Mrs Hilda Courtney; a villain with a dab hand at disguise. Courtney leads a criminal gang that's in a race against Holmes to recover the Bank Of England's printing plates for £5 notes, hidden somewhere in London by her gaoled accomplice.

References to 2 actual Sherlock Holmes stories, A Scandal in Bohemia, and the Solitary Cyclist. The smoke bomb ploy was adapted from Scandal in Bohemia as mentioned by Holmes in the story. Certainly the mention of Irene Adler was to be a metaphor for this story involving Hilda Courtney.

During the UCLA Sherlock Holmes Restoration Project (1993-2003) they were unable to find any 35mm elements of the main title for this film. The restored version uses a blow-up from a used 16mm television syndication print which was dissolved into the proper point. The main title of the restored version shows a decrease in resolution, increased grain and a reduction in image registration.

Visiting the Universal commissary for her lunch whilst still wearing Hilda Courtney's cockney disguise, Patricia Morison was sternly ordered by the maitre d' to eat with the rest of the extras at the counter, rather than at the actors' tables.

Final Quote:

Hopkins: I still don’t understand how you solved it, Mr. Holmes.

Holmes: It’s entirely due to Dr. Watson. He gave me the clue when he mentioned Dr. Samuel Johnson.

Hopkins: Well congratulations, doctor!

Watson: I don’t think I could have done it entirely without Mr. Holmes’ help, you know.
